title: Location: 'In the' (Σε + Το = Στο)
reading_greek:
THE FORMULA (Se + Article)
Σε + το = Στο (In the/To the - Neuter)
Σε + τον = Στον (In the/To the - Masc)
Σε + την = Στην (In the/To the - Fem)

EXAMPLES
1. Είμαι στο σπίτι. (I am in the house.)
2. Πάω στο σχολείο. (I go to school.)
3. Μένω στην Αθήνα. (I live in Athens - Fem).
4. Ο καφές είναι στο τραπέζι. (The coffee is on the table.)
5. Βλέπω τον Πέτρο στο πάρκο. (I see Peter in the park.)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: PREPOSITIONS [(See Page 72)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=72)

1. THE LITTLE WORD 'SE': It means 'in', 'at', or 'to'. 

2. COMBINATION: Greek hates small words next to each other. 'Se' combines with the 'The' (to/ton/tin).
   - Se + To -> STO (Neuter)
   - Se + Ton -> STON (Masculine)
   - Se + Tin -> STIN (Feminine)

3. MOVEMENT vs STATIC: It's the same! 
   - 'I go TO the house' = Pao STO spiti.
   - 'I stay IN the house' = Meno STO spiti.
audio_script:
Where are you? 

To answer this, you need the preposition 'Se'. But 'Se' is sticky. It glues itself to the Article.

Imagine 'Se' + 'To' (The). Smush them together: 'STO'. 
'Sto spiti' (In the house).

If the word is Feminine (H), use 'STIN'. 
'Stin Ellada' (In Greece).

If the word is Masculine (O), use 'STON'. 
'Ston dromo' (On the street).

This one little sound 'St-' covers 'In', 'At', 'On', and 'To'. Very efficient!
